citation.article-title: Thermosyntropha lipolytica gen. nov., sp. nov., a lipolytic, anaerobic, alkalitolerant, thermophilic bacterium utilizing short- and long-chain fatty acids in syntrophic coculture with a methanogenic archaeum.

p.s: Description of Thermosyntropha lipolytica sp. nov.

Thermosyntropha lipolytica (li.po.ly'ti.ca. Gr. n. lipos, fat; Gr. adj. lytikos, able to loosen; M.L. adj. lipolytica, referring to the property of being able to hydrolyze lipids from the formation of fatty acids and glycerol)
The cells are straight or slightly curved rods, 0.3 to 0.4 by 2.0 to 3.5 μm.
Most cells occur in the exponential growth phase in pairs or chains.
Motility or spores have not been observed.
The organism is a peptidolytic and lipolytic chemoorganotroph.
Oleate, linoleate, and the saturated fatty acids butyrate (only slowly metabolized) up to stearate are β-oxidized in syntrophic association with an H2-utilizing microorganism.
All T. lipolytica isolates are alkalitolerant thermophiles growin between 52 and 70°C (optimum, 60 to 66°C) and in a pH25°C range from 7.15 to 9.5 (optimum, 8.1 to 8.9).
The DNA base composition is 43 to 44 mol% G+C.
Strain JW/VS-265T (DSM 11003) is the type strain of T. lipolytica.
It has a G+C content of 44 mol%.
